content: The Act titled "Restoring Disability Benefits for Injured and Wounded Warriors Act of 2007" reviews and takes action on certain determinations of the Physical Evaluation Board. The Secretary of Defense appoints a panel from the private sector to review cases where the Physical Evaluation Board discharged members without assigning a disability rating. The Evaluation Board reviews cases where a member of the Armed Forces appeals the disability rating determination. They determine if a liaison officer or attorney was assigned, and assess if the case warrants reopening for a disability rating assignment. The Evaluation Board reviews cases of Armed Forces members appealing disability rating determinations, with a focus on increasing disability benefits. The review covers cases from September 11, 2001, to the present, with access to necessary information for the panel's assessments. Reports are due within 60 days of the enactment of this Act. The panel appointed under subsection (a) must submit reports to the Secretary of Defense and the Secretary of the military department concerned every 60 days on cases reviewed, including results and determinations. The Secretary of the military department concerned must re-evaluate cases covered by the panel's reports. The panel appointed under subsection (a) reviews cases every 60 days and submits reports to the Secretary of Defense and the military department. Subsection (b)(4) allows for the re-opening of cases to assign or increase disability ratings for Armed Forces members. Disability ratings subject to re-evaluation cannot be reduced. The Secretary of Defense will prescribe guidelines and procedures for the re-evaluation process. The re-evaluation process for disability ratings must be completed within 180 days. If a rating is assigned or increased, the member's record will be corrected with the effective date of the change. The member's record will be corrected with the effective date of the original determination under the case by the Physical Evaluation Board regarding the disability. SEC. 3. REVIEW AND ACTION ON DETERMINATIONS ON BENEFITS UNDER TRAUMATIC SERVICEMEMBERS GROUP LIFE INSURANCE. The Secretary of Defense appoints a panel from the private sector to review cases of denied traumatic injury protection for Armed Forces members under section 1980A of title 38, United States Code, and appeals of awarded amounts. The Secretary of Defense appoints a panel to review cases of denied traumatic injury protection for Armed Forces members under section 1980A of title 38, United States Code, and appeals of awarded amounts. The panel will determine if cases warrant reopening for additional payment of traumatic injury protection for qualifying losses claimed by the member. The Secretary of Defense appoints a panel to review cases under section 1980A of title 38, United States Code. The panel will have access to necessary information and submit reports every 60 days until reviews are completed. The Secretary of Defense appoints a panel to review cases under section 1980A of title 38, United States Code. The panel re-evaluates cases for paying traumatic injury protection or increasing previous payments under specific circumstances. The Secretary of Defense appoints a panel to review cases under section 1980A of title 38, United States Code. The re-evaluation of cases may not result in reduced payments and must be completed within 180 days. Guidelines and procedures for the re-evaluation are set by the Secretary of Defense. If a case is reconsidered, the Secretary may correct records and determine payment. When the Secretary of Defense determines to pay or increase traumatic injury protection for a member of the Armed Forces under section 1980A of title 38, United States Code, the member's record shall be corrected with the effective date being the original determination date on the qualifying loss claimed. SEC. 4. ADEQUACY OF ASSIGNMENT OF JUDGE ADVOCATES TO PHYSICAL EVALUATION BOARD CASES. The Secretary of Defense must submit a report to Congress within 60 days of this Act's enactment, assessing the adequacy of judge advocates assigned to Physical Evaluation Board cases and recommending the number needed for efficient case disposition. The term "advocate" is defined in section 801 of title 10, United States Code. SEC. 5. COMPTROLLER GENERAL REPORTS ON DISABILITY CLAIMS PROCESSES. The Comptroller General of the United States is required to submit a report to Congress within 180 days, assessing the Department of Defense's efforts to address deficiencies in the military disability evaluation systems. This report will focus on harmonizing procedures and practices within the Department. The Comptroller General of the United States is required to submit a report to Congress within 180 days, assessing the Department of Defense's efforts to address deficiencies in the military disability evaluation systems. This includes harmonizing procedures, monitoring compliance, improving oversight by the Disability Advisory Council, and enhancing the collection and processing of data. Improving data collection, processing, and entry under military disability evaluation systems, enhancing training programs for data processors, oversight of staff training, availability of liaison officers to the Physical Evaluation Board, utilization of line-of-duty determinations for Armed Forces members, and improving care for wounded National Guard members. The curr_chunk discusses improving quality assurance mechanisms for disability determination for wounded National Guard and Reserve members receiving medical treatment away from home. Additionally, it mentions a report on the adequacy of the schedule for rating disabilities of the Department of Veterans Affairs in recognizing disabilities incurred in the Global War on Terror. The curr_chunk discusses the impact of injuries incurred in the Global War on Terror, such as traumatic brain injuries, amputations, spinal injuries, PTSD, and hearing loss. It also calls for a report on the standards and procedures of the Physical Evaluation Board of the Department of Defense. The curr_chunk discusses recommendations for improving the standards and procedures of the Physical Evaluation Board of the Department of Defense, including member selection, timeliness of proceedings, witness participation, legal assistance availability, and other relevant board matters. The Comptroller General will establish standards and procedures to enhance the activities of the Physical Evaluation Board.
